functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

msg.content: Who is the mayor of each of the sixth to ninth most populous cities currently in the United States?
Who is the mayor of each of the sixth to ninth most populous cities currently in the United States?

First, I'll need to find out which cities are 6th through 9th most populous, then look up their current mayors.

This list presents only the portion of such consolidated city-counties that are not a part of another incorporated place.

msg.content: Who is the current mayor of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania?
Let me search for information about Philadelphia's current mayor.

<document>
<title>Cherelle Parker</title>
<fragment>

In January 2020, Parker defeated Bobby Henon to become majority leader for Democrats on the city council.[9] In February 2021, Parker was elected to the chair of the board for the Delaware River Port Authority.[10]



## 2023 Philadelphia mayoral campaign

[edit]

### Primary election

[edit]

Main article: 2023 Philadelphia mayoral election

On September 7, 2022, Parker resigned from the City Council and announced her candidacy for Mayor of Philadelphia in the 2023 election.[4] Following her resignation, she registered as a state lobbyist, representing Longwood Gardens and Moore College of Art and Design.[11]

**Cherelle Lesley Parker** (born September 10, 1972)[1] is an American politician and Mayor-elect of Philadelphia. She defeated David Oh as the Democratic nominee in the 2023 Philadelphia mayoral election. When sworn in on January 2, 2024, she will be the first woman to hold the position.[2][3]


Parker served in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from 2005 to 2015, representing the 200th district in Northwest Philadelphia. She was elected to represent the ninth district on the Philadelphia City Council in 2015 and re-elected in 2019, serving as majority leader from 2020 to 2022.


In September 2022, Parker resigned from City Council and announced her candidacy for Mayor of Philadelphia.[4] She won the Democratic primary on May 16, 2023.[5]

Parker married Ben Mullins, a leader in the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, in 2010.[35] They live in the Mount Airy section of Philadelphia.[36]


In 2011, Parker was arrested for driving under the influence of alcohol and driving the wrong way on a one-way street.[37] She was convicted and lost her appeal in 2015. She began serving her sentence of three days in jail, a $1,000 fine, and a one-year license suspension.[38]

In 2023, Parker supported opening schools for a longer duration of the day and mandatory year-round schooling, arguing that "children are no longer working the farms in summertime."[28] She proposed launching a pilot program, as well as increasing allocation of real estate taxes that go toward the Philadelphia School District from 55% to 58% to accommodate for the increased air conditioning costs associated with longer operating hours in the school year.[29][30]



### Public safety

[edit]

Parker's platform has been described as "tough on crime".[30] Parker opposes supervised injection sites.[31] She supports Terry stops, also known as "constitutional stop-and-frisk",[32] after having previously fought to end its supposedly unconstitutional and discriminatory use.[33] In a 2022 op-ed written on *The Philadelphia Inquirer*, Parker pledged to hire 300 additional police officers.[34]



## Personal life

[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Parker agreed to have a joint interview with Oh at the Please Touch Museum where the pair took questions from Children for their vision of Philadelphia. There, Parker stated that she wishes to see Philadelphia be the "safest, cleanest, and greenest big city in the nation, with economic opportunity for all."[25] Shortly afterwards Parker agreed to face off against Oh in a single debate on October 26 over the radio on *Philadelphia’s Morning News* on KYW.[26] As of September 27 Parker has only taken on an additional $875,000 in campaign donations compared to her $2.2 million during the primaries, outspending Oh (who raised $467,000) nearly 2:1.[27]



## Political positions

### Education

[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
Parker was born in the Mount Airy neighborhood of Northwest Philadelphia to an unmarried teenage mother. Her mother died when Parker was 11, and she was raised by her grandparents, a disabled Navy veteran and a domestic worker who both grew up in the South.[6] In 1990, as a senior at Parkway High School, Parker won a citywide oratorical contest; in addition to receiving a cash prize and a trip to Senegal and Morocco, she was introduced to then-City Councilmember Marian B. Tasco, who hired Parker as an intern.[7]


Parker graduated from Lincoln University in 1994 and briefly worked as a high school English teacher in Pleasantville, New Jersey, before returning to Councilmember Tasco's office in 1995, filling a variety of roles for the next decade.[6]

**Ronald Adrian Nirenberg** (born April 11, 1977)[1] is an American politician who is the mayor of San Antonio, Texas. Prior to his election, Nirenberg served as a member of the San Antonio City Council for District 8 for two terms.[2]

On March 18, 2020, Nirenberg issued an order for the temporary closure of all non-essential businesses in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, making San Antonio the last major city in Texas to do so.[49][50] In 2021, Nirenberg criticized Texas Governor Greg Abbott's lifting of COVID-19 mandates and prohibition on local governments from being able to make their own, saying the governor was showing "callous disregard for life."[51] The City of San Antonio, led by Nirenberg, and Bexar County sued Abbott in Bexar County court to temporarily block his executive order barring local mandates.[52] A Bexar County judge issued the restraining order on Abbott's executive order, reinstating Nirenberg's mask mandate; a ruling that he applauded.[53] The Supreme Court of Texas would later block Nirenberg's mask mandate.[54]


Upon the completion of his fourth term, Nireberg is expected to be among the longest serving mayors of San Antonio,[55] and the longest since Mayor Henry Cisneros, who left office in 1989.[56]

### 2017 San Antonio mayoral race[edit]


Main article: 2017 San Antonio mayoral election

On December 10, 2016, Nirenberg became the leading challenger to Ivy Taylor for her position as mayor of San Antonio.[12] On May 6, 2017, the first round of voting was held, with no candidate reaching the required majority of 50% of the vote. Nirenberg and Taylor finished with the two highest vote totals and advanced to a runoff election held June 10, 2017. Although Nirenberg trailed Taylor in the first municipal election, he went on to defeat Taylor 54.59–45.41% in the runoff election.[13] In so doing, Nirenberg became the first person in twenty years to defeat an incumbent mayor of San Antonio who sought re-election.[14][15]



### 2019 San Antonio mayoral race[edit]


Main article: 2019 San Antonio mayoral election

Nirenberg declared his candidacy for re-election to the office on January 29, 2019.[16] His main opponent was identified as Greg Brockhouse, a member of the San Antonio City Council who also took office in 2017 and frequently objected to Nirenberg's platform.[17] The election was scheduled for May 4, 2019, but since no majority was reached by any candidate, a runoff election was held on June 8.[18] In the runoff, Nirenberg was elected to a second term, defeating Brockhouse by a 51.11% to 48.89% final vote.[19]



### 2021 San Antonio mayoral race[edit]


Main article: 2021 San Antonio mayoral election

Nirenberg declared his candidacy for re-election for a third term in office on January 22, 2021.[20] The election was held on May 1, 2021.[21] Due to the close runoff in 2019 between Nirenberg and Brockhouse, they were considered by political watchers to be the two front-runner candidates in the election.[22] Nirenberg won his third term as mayor with 61.89% of the vote, while Brockhouse received 31.26%.[23]

### 2023 San Antonio mayoral race[edit]


Main article: 2023 San Antonio mayoral election

Nirenberg declared his candidacy for re-election for a fourth term in office on January 26, 2023.[24] Due to term limits if Nirenberg won, it would be his last term. Nirenberg faced minimal opposition and was expected to win re-election. On May 6, 2023, the election was held and Nirenberg was re-elected with an unofficial count of over 61% of the vote.[4]



## Tenure[edit]

Although Nirenberg identifies as an independent[25] and ran for office as a nonpartisan politician,[a] he has been described as ideologically progressive.[26][27][28][29]

Upon the resignation of Mayor Bob Filner on August 30, 2013,[20] Gloria became the interim mayor of San Diego, with limited powers.[21] This made San Diego the second largest city in the United States (after Houston) to have an openly gay mayor at that time.[22][23] He served until March 3, 2014, when mayor-elect Kevin Faulconer was sworn in. While serving as interim mayor, he remained the City Councilmember for District 3 and retained the title of City Council President; however, City Council President Pro Tem Sherri Lightner carried out the duties of the Council President.[24] Gloria was considered a possible candidate to replace Filner but chose not to run.[25]

**Todd Rex Gloria** (born May 10, 1978)[1][2] is an American politician serving as the 37th and current mayor of San Diego since 2020. As mayor, he is the chief executive officer in the city of San Diego. A member of the Democratic Party, he is the first person of color[a] and the first openly gay person to serve as San Diego's mayor.


Gloria was first elected to public office representing District 3 of the San Diego City Council. He was president of the nine-member council from 2012 through 2014. In his role as council president, Gloria served as interim Mayor of San Diego from the August 2013 resignation of Mayor Bob Filner until the March 2014 inauguration of Mayor Kevin Faulconer.[3] Gloria was then elected to represent California's 78th State Assembly district, which encompasses much of San Diego. While in the Assembly, he served as House Majority Whip.[4] In December 2020 he became the 37th Mayor of San Diego.[5]

By doing so, Gloria aimed to unify San Diego's allocated resources in the fight to end homelessness in the city.In December 2012, at its first meeting after new members took office, Gloria was unanimously elected to serve as Council President, replacing retiring President Tony Young.[18]

### Mayor of Dallas[edit]


Main article: 2019 Dallas mayoral election

On June 8, 2019, Johnson was elected mayor of Dallas, defeating his opponent, city councilman Scott Griggs,[11] in a runoff election. It was announced that he would take office on June 17, 2019.[12][13] With his election, Johnson became the second African-American mayor to be elected in Dallas history (the first being Ron Kirk) and one of the youngest mayors of a major American city. He was sworn in as mayor on June 17, 2019, by U.S. District Court Judge Sam Lindsay.[14]

**Eric Lynn Johnson**[1] (born October 10, 1975) is an American politician and attorney who has served as the 60th mayor of Dallas, Texas since June 2019. Johnson was born on October 10, 1975, in Dallas, Texas. He attended Dallas ISD schools until the second grade, when he received a scholarship to attend Greenhill School through the West Dallas Boys & Girls Club. Johnson graduated from Greenhill School in 1994.[3]

On September 22, 2023, Johnson announced he was switching parties to become a Republican, stating that his views on police, low property taxes, and being pro-business was more in line with the Republican platform than a Democratic one. In response, the chair and vice-chair of the Texas Democratic Party rebuked Johnson as "an ineffective and truant mayor". Several other Dallas Democrats also expressed disapproval. However, Texas Republicans, including governor Greg Abbott and Texas House of Representatives speaker Dade Phelan, commended Johnson on his decision. As a result of Johnson's party switch, Dallas became the largest city in the United States with a Republican mayor, surpassing Fort Worth, also located in Texas.[43]

In the 2023 Dallas mayoral election, where Johnson did not have any official challengers, of the 2,675 write-ins cast, two Dallas voters had cast a vote for "Bruh".[74]



## Personal life[edit]


Johnson lives in Dallas with his wife, Nikki and their three children.[75] In 2021, he became the first mayor in Dallas history to have a child while in office. He is a member of Mountain View Church of Christ.[76]

During Johnson's tenure, the City of Dallas added more than $14 billion in new development and welcomed major corporations, including multiple Fortune 500 companies like Goldman Sachs, AECOM, CBRE, and Frontier Communications, that moved their headquarters or significant operations to the City of Dallas.[18] The City of Dallas has reduced the city's property tax rate every year since Johnson became mayor, including passing the largest single-year tax rate reduction in 40 years in 2022.[19]


Johnson appointed Garrett Boone as the "Greening Czar". Boone is tasked with choosing from hundreds of possible park sites all around Dallas. [20]

At his inauguration, Johnson vowed to bring civility back to Dallas City Hall.[59] This was a rebuke to what many saw as an aggressive style by some members of the Dallas City Council, which turned off some voters.[60] Since becoming mayor, political opponents and online commentators have tried to portray him as unforgiving and demanding.[61] In addition, online commentators have criticized him for occasionally missing parts of Dallas City Council meetings, over which he is the presiding officer. Johnson has also been engaged in political disputes with other government officials, including the city manager.[62] In 2021, Johnson said he was "open to trying different things" and was later lauded by *The Dallas Morning News* for his committee assignments that seemed to embody a different approach in a new City Council term.[63][64]

msg.content: Based on the search results, Eric Johnson is the current (60th) mayor of Dallas, Texas. He has served in this role since June 17, 2019. Johnson was elected mayor in June 2019 after defeating city councilman Scott Griggs in a runoff election. He is the second African-American mayor in Dallas history (after Ron Kirk). Recently, in September 2023, Johnson switched his party affiliation from Democratic to Republican, making Dallas the largest U.S. city with a Republican mayor. He was recently re-elected in 2023 and continues to serve as the incumbent mayor of Dallas.
